Introduction

Respiratory gas exchange involves the following processes:



  • Oxygenation (oxygen extraction in the lungs).
  • Ventilation (carbon dioxide elimination by the lungs).
  • Oxygen and carbon dioxide transport in the blood.
  • Respiratory quotient (carbon dioxide produced per oxygen consumed).


This article discusses these processes, how they are regulated at rest, and how they respond during exercise.

Oxygenation



Oxygenation refers to the extraction of oxygen in the lungs.  Normal oxygenation requires:



  • Normal inspired oxygen (ie, PiO2).
  • Normal alveolar ventilation (ie, PaCO2), which requires normal minute ventilation and dead space.
  • Normal alveolar-capillary exchange (ie, A-a gradient), which requires:
    • Proper ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) matching.
    • Efficient diffusion.

V/Q matching



Ventilation (V) and perfusion (Q) matching can be conceptualized as the opportunity for oxygen uptake.  Wherever air (ventilation) is present, there should be corresponding blood flow (perfusion).  When ventilation is wasted on areas with insufficient blood flow (ie, dead space) or when perfusion is wasted on areas with insufficient ventilation (ie, shunt), V/Q mismatching occurs.



Ventilation and perfusion both decrease from the lung bases to the lung apices (

figure 1
):



  • Ventilation is slightly greater at the lung bases because basal alveoli, compressed by overlying lung weight, start smaller and can expand relatively more during inspiration; conversely, apical alveoli are already stretched open and expand less.
  • Perfusion is significantly greater at the lung bases due to the effect of gravity.  Gravity increases hydrostatic pressure in the pulmonary arteries (PAs), allowing blood to flow continuously (because the PA blood pressure exceeds the alveolar air pressure).  At the apices, PA pressure falls below alveolar pressure; as a result, capillaries are compressed and perfusion is reduced.

V/Q ratios



Based on the relative pressures of the PAs, alveoli, and pulmonary veins, the lung is traditionally divided into 3 zones of West (named after physiologist John West) (

figure 2
):



  • Zone 1 (apices and upper lobes):  Ventilation is low at the apices because the already distended alveoli have limited capacity to expand further during inspiration.  Perfusion is even lower because hydrostatic PA pressure is reduced at the apices, allowing alveoli to compress the capillaries and limit blood flow (alveolar pressure > PA pressure).  As a result, the V/Q is >1 (often >2).  This zone has a dead space tendency (ie, wasted ventilation) due to relative underperfusion.
  • Zone 2 (midlung):  Ventilation is intermediate because the alveoli are moderately compressed and capable of further expansion during inspiration.  Perfusion is also intermediate because the increasing hydrostatic PA pressure toward the lung bases helps keep the capillaries from being compressed by alveolar pressure (PA pressure > alveolar pressure).  As a result, the V/Q ~1.  This zone has ideal V/Q matching.
  • Zone 3 (bases and lower lobes):  Ventilation is high at the bases because the basal alveoli expand the most during inspiration.  Perfusion is even higher because the gravitational hydrostatic pressure in the PAs keeps the vessels open.  As a result, the V/Q is <1.  This zone has shunt tendency due to relative overperfusion.


At rest, V/Q ratios normally range from 3 at the apices to ~0.6 at the bases, with a global average ratio of ~1 for the entire lung.  The spread of the V/Q ratios is often represented as a histogram centered at 1 (

figure 3
).

V/Q with exercise



At rest, the V/Q ratio is ~3 at the apices, as described previously.  During exercise, a rise in cardiac output recruits the capillaries in the apices and upper lobes, increasing perfusion in these regions.  As a result, apical perfusion increases, lowering the V/Q ratio toward 1.  This enables V/Q matching to improve even further with exercise compared to at rest, optimizing oxygen uptake efficiency.  Consequently, a slight increase in PaO2 is considered a normal oxygenation response during exercise.  Desaturation is never normal.

Diffusion



Perfect V/Q matching brings air and blood into close proximity, but oxygenation is not complete unless oxygen effectively crosses the alveolar-capillary membrane, a process known as diffusion.  Normal diffusion is governed by Fick law (

figure 4
).  The 2 most important variables in Fick laws of diffusion are the following:



  • Alveolar membrane surface area (A) determines the total area available for diffusion, with increased area increasing diffusion.  Membrane surface area is normally 100 m2 in a healthy adult (approximately the size of a tennis court).  It is reduced by conditions such as lung resection (eg, lobectomy) and emphysema.
  • Alveolar membrane thickness (T) determines the distance that oxygen needs to cross, with increased thickness decreasing diffusion.  Membrane thickness is normally 0.5 μm in a healthy adult and comprises 3 layers (epithelium, basement membrane, endothelium).  Thickness is increased by conditions such as interstitial lung disease and pulmonary edema.


The other variables include the diffusion coefficient (D) (a unique value for each gas representing its solubility [eg, highest for carbon dioxide]) and partial pressure difference (ΔP) across the membrane (increased by altering the pressure or purity of inhaled gas).

Diffusion with exercise



Oxygen diffuses quickly enough to fully equilibrate between the alveoli and the capillary blood within the first third of the pulmonary capillary.  This rapid diffusion prevents hypoxemia during exercise (eg, even when blood flow triples).  Because diffusion reaches an early ceiling, oxygen uptake can be increased further only by greater perfusion.  As a result, in healthy individuals, oxygen uptake is said to be perfusion limited.  However, in individuals with alveolar membrane damage (eg, due to severe emphysema or interstitial lung disease), oxygenation can become diffusion limited (

figure 5
).  Oxygenation might be marginally normal at rest, but significant desaturation can often be revealed by exertion.

Ventilation



Ventilation refers to the elimination of carbon dioxide by the lungs.  It requires normal alveolar ventilation (VA).  Therefore, alveolar hypoventilation and hypercapnia (ie, PaCO2 >45 mm Hg) are synonymous.

Minute ventilation



Minute ventilation (VE) is the total respired volume per minute.  It is calculated as the product of tidal volume (VT) and respiratory rate (RR) (VE = VT · RR).  Normal VT is approximately 500 mL, and normal RR is 12/min, yielding a typical VE of 6 L/min.

Alveolar ventilation



Alveolar ventilation (VA) is the total respired volume that participates in alveolar gas exchange.  It is equal to VE minus the dead space ventilation (VD).  Dead space is the fraction of VT that is unavailable for exchange.  There are 2 components of VD (

figure 6
):



  • Anatomic VD is created by the conducting airways, such as the trachea and bronchi, where no gas exchange occurs.  In adults, this is a fixed value of roughly 150 mL, so only 350 mL of a normal 500-mL VT ever reaches the alveoli.  As VT decreases, the anatomic dead space fraction increases (
    figure 7
    ).  For example, with a 300-mL VT, only 150 mL reaches the alveoli.
  • Alveolar VD is created by alveoli with very high V/Q ratios (eg, extreme lung apices), where perfusion is low compared to ventilation.  Under normal conditions, alveolar dead space is minimal (eg, 5-10 mL), but it can be greatly increased by conditions that reduce perfusion (eg, pulmonary embolism).


VA is calculated as VA = (VT − VD) · RR.  Therefore, in normal conditions, VA = (500 − 150) · 12 = 4.2 L/min.  A slower, deeper breathing pattern (eg, VT = 600 mL, RR = 10/min) is preferable to a faster, shallower one (eg, VT = 300 mL, RR = 20/min), even if VE is the same (eg, 6 L/min for both).  The shallow pattern results in a lower VA because more VT is wasted in anatomic dead space.

PaCO2



PaCO2 is directly proportional to the carbon dioxide production rate (VCO2) and inversely proportional to VA (ie, PaCO2 ∝ VCO2 / VA):



  • VCO2 (ie, ventilatory load) is determined by metabolic rate.  It increases with exercise, pathologic conditions (eg, fever, hyperthyroidism, sepsis, burns, trauma), and overfeeding (especially with a carbohydrate-rich diet).
  • VA is determined by VE and dead space, as discussed previously.


Normally, a rise in VCO2 is accompanied by a proportional rise in VA.  Peripheral and central chemoreceptors rapidly adjust ventilation to maintain arterial carbon dioxide within a normal range.  If VA fails to keep pace with VCO2, acute hypercapnic respiratory failure results.  This is seen in severe exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, when patients generate more carbon dioxide from their own work of breathing than they can expel through ventilation.

Ventilation with exercise



Exercise leads to increases in both VT and RR.  The respiratory response differs based on the presence of lung disease:



  • Healthy:  With exercise that is low-to-moderate intensity, VT increases first.  With higher-intensity exercise, RR increases as VT approaches inspiratory capacity.
  • Abnormal:  In patients with lung disease or neuromuscular weakness, RR increases earlier and more sharply because VT cannot increase sufficiently.


In other words, VT is the primary mechanism for increasing ventilation, whereas RR becomes more important as ventilatory load increases.  In clinical practice, persistent tachypnea at rest often signals a serious underlying illness.

Gas transport

Oxygen transport



Oxygen is transported in the blood in 2 forms:



  • Some 98.5% of oxygen is bound to hemoglobin (HbO2).  Each gram of hemoglobin can carry 1.34 mL of oxygen when fully saturated (ie, SaO2 100%).
  • Some 1.5% of oxygen is carried as a dissolved gas in the plasma (PaO2).  Only 0.003 mL of oxygen can dissolve in each deciliter of blood per every 1 mm Hg of increase in partial pressure.


Total blood oxygen content (CaO2) is the sum of HbO2 and PaO2:



CaO2 = HbO2 + PaO2= (1.34 · SaO2 · Hb) + (0.003 · PaO2)



In a healthy patient with normal hemoglobin (eg, Hb = 15 g/dL) and normal oxygenation (eg, SaO2 = 99%, PaO2 = 90 mm Hg), the oxygen carrying capacity is 20.1 mL O2/dL of blood.



Carrying capacity is determined almost entirely by hemoglobin concentration.  For example, when a patient with severe anemia (eg, Hb = 5 mg/dL) is breathing pure oxygen (ie, SaO2 = 99%, PaO2 = 600 mm Hg), the oxygen-carrying capacity is only 8.43 mL O2/dL of blood (only 42% of normal).  Therefore, the total CaO2 remains very low despite maximizing the dissolved oxygen.

Carbon dioxide transport



Carbon dioxide is transported in the blood in 3 forms:



  • 70% of carbon dioxide is transported as bicarbonate anion (HCO3−).
  • 23% of carbon dioxide is transported as carbaminohemoglobin (HbCO2).
  • 7% of carbon dioxide is carried as a dissolved gas in the plasma (PaCO2).


These 3 states are in an equilibrium mediated by carbonic anhydrase in red blood cells (

figure 8
).  When PaCO2 increases, more HCO3− is formed and subsequently transported out of red blood cells in exchange for chloride anions to maintain electrical neutrality (ie, Hamburger phenomenon).  This phenomenon is one of the reasons that metabolic alkalosis (excess plasma HCO3−) is often accompanied by hypochloremia.



Some of the carbon dioxide binds to the terminal amine group of hemoglobin as carbaminohemoglobin; when exposed to high levels of oxygen in the lungs, the hemoglobin releases carbon dioxide so that it can bind oxygen instead (ie, Haldane and Bohr effects) (

figure 9
).  This phenomenon contributes to oxygen-induced hypercapnia in patients with marginal VA (sometimes called "chronic carbon dioxide retainers") who receive excessive supplemental oxygen (
figure 10
).

Respiratory quotient



The respiratory quotient (RQ), sometimes referred to as the respiratory exchange ratio, is the ratio between carbon dioxide production and oxygen consumption (RQ = VCO2 / VO2).  The RQ is mainly affected by dietary composition and exercise.

Effect of dietary composition



Carbohydrates, fats, and proteins have differing RQ levels:



  • The RQ of carbohydrates is ~1 because complete oxidation of glucose produces 6 molecules of carbon dioxide and consumes 6 molecules of oxygen (C6H12O6 + 6 O2 → 6 CO2 + 6 H2O + 32 ATP).
  • The RQ of fats is ~0.7 because complete oxidation of a long-chain fatty acid (eg, palmitic acid) produces ~16 molecules of carbon dioxide and consumes 23 molecules of oxygen (C16H32O2 + 23 O2 → 16 CO2 + 16 H2O + 106 ATP).
  • The RQ of proteins is ~0.85 because complete oxidation of amino acids through intermediate reactions (eg, gluconeogenesis) produces 5 molecules of carbon dioxide and consumes 6 molecules of oxygen (eg, alanine [C3H7​NO2] ​+ 6 O2 → 5 CO2 + 3 H2O + 15 ATP).


For a normal Western diet, the overall RQ is ~0.8.  This value is used in the alveolar gas equation (PAO2 = PiO2 − PaCO2 / RQ = 150 − PaCO2 / 0.8).



Overfeeding with high-carbohydrate diets can increase RQ and contribute to worsening hypercapnia in patients with underlying respiratory failure.  Therefore, fat- and protein-rich diets are often preferred to help reduce RQ and assist with respiratory recovery (eg, ventilator weaning).

Effect of exercise



The RQ increases during exercise.  At rest or during routine activity, the RQ is approximately 0.8.  With more intense exercise, tissues preferentially use carbohydrates for fuel, causing the RQ to increase toward 1.  With very-high-intensity exercise, the RQ increases further and can exceed 1 as the anaerobic threshold is reached (ie, oxygen is no longer being consumed, but carbon dioxide is still being produced from glycolysis).

Summary



Respiratory gas exchange encompasses the processes of oxygenation, ventilation, and gas transport in the blood.



Effective oxygenation requires normal alveolar-capillary exchange.  It requires tight ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) matching (ie, opportunity for air to contact blood) and rapid diffusion across the alveolar membrane (ie, speed of oxygen uptake).  V/Q mismatch or diffusion limitation leads to impaired alveolar-capillary exchange and a subsequent fall in PaO2 (ie, hypoxemia).  Blood oxygen content is mainly carried by hemoglobin (98.5%).



Effective ventilation requires normal minute ventilation (tidal volume · respiratory rate) and minimal dead space volume.  Insufficient minute ventilation or abnormally increased dead space leads to alveolar hypoventilation and a subsequent rise in PaCO2 (ie, hypercapnia), which can also cause secondary hypoxemia.  Blood carbon dioxide content is mainly carried as intracellular bicarbonate in red blood cells (70%).
